article_title: Party line divides hopefuls in Texas House District 118
article_text:
Party line divides hopefuls in Texas House District 118 Special election is Nov. 3 for District 118 vacancy

Photo: Juanito M Garza / San Antonio Express-News Anthony Alcoser, candidate for Texas House District 118 talks to...

Three Democrats and three Republicans vying to succeed state Rep. Joe Farias all have hopes of improving education and business opportunities in Texas House District 118, and they offer an array of ideas for achieving those goals.

article_metadata.description: Three Democrats and three Republicans vying to succeed state Rep. Joe Farias all have hopes of improving education and business opportunities in Texas House District 118, and they offer an array of ideas for achieving those goals.  Divided on party lines on key legislative issues, the candidates are competing in a special election Nov. 3 to replace Farias, who served the district from 2007 until his recent resignation.  The GOP candidates rail against abortion, Obamacare, Medicaid expansion, wasteful government spending and ineffective federal border security.  Early voting starts Oct. 19, and with such a large field in an off-year special election, the competition could result in a runoff on Jan. 19 if no one wins a majority to complete Farias’ term through 2016.  A retired 25-year firefighter who also worked as a sheriff’s deputy, Lujan is vice president of sales for a tech company.  Farias, the broadcast voice of UIW Cardinals football and a chamber of commerce executive, hopes to carry on his father’s work for the district but also statewide for veterans, students and the disadvantaged.  Bringing a youthful vigor to the race, Alcoser wants to apply his experience on the Harlandale school board and his skills raising funds for a university to the larger mission of improving the district and state.  Casias emphasizes “selfless service,” adding that he’s “not a politician” but still brings “a vast array of national and international experience to decision-making and leading large organizations.”  With public school funding a major concern and troubling disparity among school districts in District 118, Holdman advocates the novel approach of eliminating school property taxes and replacing them with a sales tax, along with allowing vouchers.
article_metadata.author.name: By John W. Gonzalez, Staff Writer
